paper prototype.notes:
PROS:
 - fast
 - promotes experimentation
 - collaborative
 - easy testing
 - establish terminology flaws early
 - determine key interactions
 - communication
 - design and think through main user flows
CONS:
 - only short term use
 - no specifics
 - no animations
 - no timing measurements (testing)
 - rudimentary for working models
 - may appear unprofessional in testing

electronic prototype.notes:
PROS:
 - specific and realistic
 - helpful to developers
 - can include technologies like interaction
CONS:
 - slower to iterate
 - costly
 - participants less comfortable critiquing in usability testing
 - can b unreliable
 - if used early causes information overload
 - on-the-go fixes not as realistic

memory.notes:
STM:
 - 'consciousness'
 - limited in capacity and duration
 - span of attention : largest # of items recognisable in a single glance
 - memory span : number of items recallable after a singe look
WORKING MEMORY : 
 - phonological loop : auditory
 - visuospatial sketchpad - visual imagery
 - central executive processor - attention control
LTM : 
 - encoding : entering LTM
 => maintenance rehearsal - repitition
 => elaboration - rehearsed in meaning
 => organisation - group in categories
- retrieval : leaving LTM
 => context and emotional state
 => recall e.g. short answer is harder than recognition e.g. MC
IMPROVING:
 - elaboration
 - organising materials
 - automating skills
 - chunking
 - imagery
 - external memory aids
 - summaires
 - mnemonic devices
 - advance organisers
ORGANISATION : 
 - schea
 - mental model 
LTM
 -> declarative
      -> semantic memory (facts)
      => episodic memory (events)
 -> procedural knowledge

cognitive load theory.notes:
Cognitive architecture : 
 - LTM, WM
 - schemas help bypass WM limitations
 - automation frees up WM capacity
 - IMPROVE LOAD THROUGH HEURISTICS
EFFECT:
 - split attention : physically split info -> cognitive strain
 - redundancy effect : unimportant info clogging WM
 - expertise reversal : good for novice may not be good for experts
 - reduce search : minimise searching as it is cognitively demanding
 - diagrams : reduce cognitive load by showing visual relationships
 - modality effect : seperate audio and visual inputs may help cognition as they have separate processors
 - animations : be careful : distracting, often needs interactivity
 - transient info : shouldn't be overloaded
Sources of cognitive load::
 - extrinsinc / extraneous
 - intrinsic
 - germane
OTHER EFFECTS:
 - Goal free effect
 - Completion effect
 - Imagination effect
 - element interactivity effect
 - guidance fading effect
 - human movement effect
